titlestmt.titleproper: National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 7, Accession 7
A Guide to the National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 7, Accession 7 FA1189

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-07-25 00:03:24 -0400.

did.unittitle: National Committee on United States-China Relations records, RG 7, Accession 7

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: National Committee on United States-China Relations, Inc.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist. When requesting audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The National Committee on United States – China Relations (NCUSCR) was established in 1966 as a nonprofit educational organization with a mission to encourage mutual understanding and dialogue between citizens of the United States and China. The National Committee came into being through the cooperative efforts of scholars and civic, religious, and business leaders who, at a time of mutual hostility between the two countries, sought to stimulate public discussion about China and the United States' relations with it by sponsoring conferences, seminars, publications, and other education and outreach programs. In 1972, the National Committee sponsored the Chinese table tennis team's historic U. S. visit. This round of "Ping Pong Diplomacy," which followed closely on Richard Nixon's visit to China in February 1972, helped pave the way for later exchanges and, eventually, for the normalization of relations with China in 1979. Building on these cultural exchanges, the National Committee came to be a primary organizer of professional and policy exchanges between the two countries (and including Hong Kong and Taiwan), in the areas of foreign affairs and international relations, economic development, governance and legal affairs, education, mass media, environmental and global issues, etc. As its role in exchanges became more prominent, the National Committee turned over some of its educational programs to the Asia Society in the late 1970s, but it continues its educational role through public education events and ongoing outreach. Funding for the National Committee comes from the United States government (especially the Department of State), corporations, and foundations, as well as from its individual membership.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The National Committee on United States-China Relations donated its records to the Rockefeller Archive Center by deed of gift dated March 27, 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the National Committee on United States – China Relations are divided into ten record groups, which reflect the order in which the records were received (but which are otherwise an artificial distinction). The records are sorted intellectually into series, which carry over through all record groups, but they have received minimal physical rearrangement. RG 7 of the NCUSCR records is arranged into fourteen series: 1 – Events; 2 – Exchanges - General; 3 – Exchanges to China; 4 – Exchanges from China; 5 – Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues; 6 – Publications and Reports; 8 – Programs, Projects, and Proposals; 9 – Ping Pong Diplomacy; 10 – Development; 11 – Board of Directors, Committees, and Members records; 12 – HIV-AIDS; 13 – ACS/ACF Programs and Staff; 15 – Clippings and Reference; and 16 – Sister Cities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: RG 7 notably includes the records of the America – China Society, from its founding in 1987 through its merger with the National Committee in 2001. Board records in RG 7 document Board and Executive Committee meetings from around 2002/2004 to 2014. Significant subjects in RG 7 include the Shenyang Acrobats' U. S. tour, 1971 – 1972, and National Committee efforts (two-way exchanges and workshops) on behalf of HIV-AIDS awareness and prevention in China. Finally, RG 7 contains information on exchange trips and conferences sponsored by other, "outside" organizations, such as the Committee on Scholarly Communication with the People's Republic of China, whose activities sometimes paralleled the National Committee's own programs.It also includes materials on Sister City programs with China.

did.unittitle: Long Yongtu Visit (Seattle, Los Angeles, and Washington, DC)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The University of Washington and the NCUSCR cosponsored Long's visit. Head of the Boao Forum on Asia, Long participated in a series of public programs and briefings on China's economic reforms and role in Asia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The General Exchanges series in RG 7 contains trip reports and other records, mainly for the 1970s – 1980s, relating to various "outside" exchanges with China, which were undertaken without the direct support and sponsorship of the National Committee. Other significant materials include correspondence with the Committee on Scholarly Communication with the People's Republic of China, 1969-1987, including files on CSCPRC delegations from China, and general assessments of exchange programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Delegation of Congresswomen to the PRC, 1975 December 30 - 1976 January 9. Congressional Foreign Policy study mission to China, 1976 April 17-23. Harlan Cleveland, China Diary, 1976. scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Programs, Projects, and Proposals series in RG 7 is rather a catch-all series, as it contains both well-formed ideas files and more random project proposals. In addition to these files on possible projects, the series includes materials relating to the National Committee's early role as a Speakers Bureau. An extensive Speakers File, compiled in the late 1960s – early 1970s, contains detailed information on a wide range of China specialists who might be referred to interested organizations.

did.unittitle: Board of Directors, Committees, and Members records

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Board, Committees, and Members series in RG 7 contains a set of Board meeting records and materials for 2002 - 2014 (there are no records for 2004) and of Executive Committee records for 2004 - 2014. These records complete the earlier runs of Board and Executive Committee records found in RG 5 and RG 6 (FA1187 and FA1188). The series also includes some mailings to Board members on topical issues, 1965 - 1967, and programming proposals for the early 1970s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The HIV-AIDS series documents exchange programs the National Committee organized between Chinese and American public-health specialists, HIV-AIDS workers, and journalists, from 2003 - 2006. In 2003, the NCUSCR sponsored a fellowship visit for three Chinese HIV-AIDS activists, who spent two months in the U. S. learning from community-level organizations engaged in education and outreach. Subsequent two-way exchange programs focused on the role of Community Planning in HIV-AIDS Policy-Making (delegation from China, October 31 - November 13, 2004) and for HIV-AIDS Prevention and Treatment in China (American specialists led workshops in Beijing and Yunnan, May 20 – June 1, 2005). A second exchange program focused on the Media's role in working to overcome stigma and discrimination and foster understanding and community engagement in the fight against HIV-AIDS. A delegation of high-level Chinese journalists visited the U. S. on a two-week study tour in the spring of 2006 (March 23 – April 7) in which they visited HIV-AIDS organizations and received special training in strategic communication techniques. The following month (May 20-31, 2006), American and Chinese specialists led journalist training workshops in Beijing, Changsha, and Guangzhou. The series also includes background readings on HIV-AIDS in China, some program materials from delegation visits and workshops, as well as information on other HIV-AIDS conferences.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Grants from the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs funded both the Community Planning and the Media exchange programs. Records pertaining to these grants are found in RG 6 (FA1188), Development series, boxes 30-31, folders 273-274, 276-279.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Additional records pertaining to the HIV-AIDS Education and Outreach Fellows visit, 2003 June 28 - August 23, are found in RG 1 (FA772), Exchanges from China series, boxes 108-109, folders 1572-1576.

America-China Society / America-China Forum Programs and Staff

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The America-China Society (ACS) was founded in 1987 by Henry Kissinger and Cyrus Vance with the goal of promoting understanding and cooperation between the People's Republic of China and the United States. Kissinger and Vance co-chaired the organization, which consisted of 35-40 Directors – business executives or former government leaders – who shared interest in China. According to its statement of purpose, "the America-China Society works to increase understanding between the United States and the PRC; to advance diplomatic, commercial, cultural, social, scientific and educational ties; to foster public policies which promote their shared interests; to enhance opportunities for United States enterprises to engage in mutually beneficial investment and trade with the PRC; and to cooperate with governmental and private organizations having comparable objectives." In January 2000, the ACS directors voted to merge with the National Committee, becoming (around 2001), the America-China Forum of the National Committee on U. S. – China Relations.

The ACS/ACF records in this series consist of Executive Directors correspondence, 1988 – 1999; Directors correspondence, late 1980s – 1990s, and correspondence with Individuals, mid- to late 1990s; organizational records and meeting minutes and materials, 1986 – 2000; records of ACS programs and events; ACS Trip files; and various office files. While some of the meeting, trip, and event files include remarks or notes by Kissinger, materials in the correspondence files pertaining to Kissinger consist mainly of informational memos to him (with marginal responses) or prepared letters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

(Shanghai Communique 20th Anniversary Commemoration, Huang Ju Luncheon), 1992 April 29 (4 pages). Roundtable Discussion Meeting, 1992 December 15 (4 sets of negatives) (see also Contact Sheets). Unidentified ACS event: 7 sets of undated color negative strips, labeled A-G.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Clippings and Reference series in RG 7 contains publications on a variety of topics relating to China, from the 1950s to the present. In addition to writings on Communist China in the mid-1960s, the series significantly includes a Clippings Book on the Harvard University Journalists' Seminar, July 13-15, 1967.

did.unittitle: Surveys on Perceptions of Asia and China (General)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mixed Messages: A Survey of the Foreign Policy Views of American Leaders, 1995. Soft Power in Asia (Survey of Public Opinion), 2009. Image: Acknowledgement and Expectation. Report of the Survey on Chinese National Status in the Eyes of the Chinese Public and the Foreigners, 2010.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: American Attitudes toward Chinese Americans and Asian Americans, 2001. US China Public Perceptions, Opinion Survey, 2012.

did.unittitle: Coverage of the United States in Key Chinese Periodicals during 1984 (David L. Shambaugh)

The Sino-Soviet Dispute, 1956-63: Extracts from Recent Documents

Propaganda Campaigns in Communist China (Vincent V. S. King)
Peking and the Latin American Communists (Ernst Halperin)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Morton H. Halperin, Is China Turning In (December 1965) and China and Nuclear Proliferation (1966). The China Puzzle, League of Women Voters, 1967. John G. Stoessinger, "The Coming of Communism to China" (1967 September). Nicholas Katzenbach, Communist China: A Realistic View, 1968 May 21. Russia, China and the West, British Information Services, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Campaign for Normalization of US - China Diplomatic Relations: A Handbook, US-China People's Friendship Association (1976). Harry Harding, Jr., China and the U.S.: Normalization and Beyond (1979). English Language Test Used by the People's Republic of China in Selecting Candidtates for Study Abroad in 1978-1979. Contemporary China (1977 May). New China (1979 Fall and Winter).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Michel Oksenberg, President Reagan's China Trip: A Background Paper (1984 April). A. Doak Barnett, After Deng, What. Will China Follow the USSR (1991). Thomas W. Robinson, "Chinese Foreign Policy Post-Tiananmen" (1994 May).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General background reading. Offprints and copies of articles and papers. Includes "Policy Impact Panel on the Future of U.S.-China Relations" (1994), with Jan Berris notes. Kenneth Lieberthal paper on "The Future of United States - China Relations: A Proposal for a Sustainable, Bipartisan Policy" (1994). NBR Analysis, The Future of China (1992 August).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Congressional Research Service Report, "China-US Relations: Current Issues and Implications for US Policy" (2007 February 14). Donald Zagoria, U.S. - China and Cross-Straight Relations: How Stable (2011).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Our Next Five Years. The Agenda for Hong Kong, Address by Governor Christopher Patten, 1992 October 7. Britain-China (Winter 1992-1993). China Rising, SAISPHERE (2006). U. S. - China Perception Monitor, 2014 January 22.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Volume 13, number 1.

did.unittitle: Clippings Book: Press Conference, June 6, 1967, and Journalists' Seminar, Harvard University, July 13-15, 1967

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence, agreements, and promotional materials relating to the establishment of "Sister" relationships between U. S. states and cities and their Chinese counterparts, from the late 1970s to the mid-1990s. The National Committee appears to have had little active involvement in the program.

National Council on U. S. - China Sister State and City Relations

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access copy currently unavailable. Researchers interested in accessing digital media in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. Please contact an archivist if you are uncertain if there is an access surrogate or to ask that one be made.
